questions.text: A man continuously calls women and achieves sexual gratification by talking obscenely and by sharing obscene pictures. This condition is termed as ________.
questions.solution:
Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of inappropriate videos/images to an unsuspecting person.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Important paraphilic disorders are:

  • Exhibitionism- Urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.
  • Fetishism- It is the use of objects for sexual gratification. Eg. shoes, gloves, pantyhose, and stockings. The objects can be used to attain gratification directly or the person may ask the partner to wear them during sexual intercourse.
  • Frotteurism- is usually characterized by a man's rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm.
  • Pedophilia- involves recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.
  • Masochism- takes its name from the activities of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, a novelist whose characters derived sexual pleasure from being abused and dominated by women.
  • Sexual sadism- The person attains sexual arousal from the physical and psychosocial suffering of another person.
  • Voyeurism- It is also called scoptophilia. The person has an urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.
  • Transvestism- Fantasies and sexual urge to dress in opposite gender clothing.
  • Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of video images to an unsuspecting partner. 
  • Necrophilia- it is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies
  • Zoophilia- having an urge to involve in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.
  • Coprophilia- Sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner or to be defected on.
  • Urophilia- the sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.
  • Hypoxyphilia- is the desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution:
The dimorphic fungus that causes subcutaneous mycosis is Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporotrichosis is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, a thermally dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation. The infection occurs following traumatic inoculation.

The lesion initially develops as a granulomatous nodule that may progress to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. The infection from the lesions in the skin and subcutaneous tissue can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This condition is known as lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. This disease is commonly encountered among gardeners and forest workers.

The image below shows lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

Other options:

Option B: Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum. It is acquired by inhalation and causes a disease similar to tuberculosis and may present as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain.

Option C: Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Option D: T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

questions.text: Identify the organisation that has the given logo

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme

questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme(NLEP)

Characteristics of NLEP emblem :

  • The lotus in the NLEP Emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb; a normal fore-finger and the shape of house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The Emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of Leprosy.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Leprosy work is not merely medical relief; it is transforming frustration of life into joy of dedication, personal ambition into selfless service- Mahatma Gandhi.

Option 1) NVBDCP

Option 2) DOTS (RNTCP)

World Leprosy Day is celebrated on 30 January. This international day is an opportunity to celebrate people who have experienced leprosy, raise awareness of the disease, and call for an end to leprosy-related stigma and discrimination. The “United for Dignity” campaign calls for unity in honoring the dignity of people who have experienced leprosy.

questions.text: A neonate is being evaluated for the finding shown in the image. The mother's prenatal history is significant for viral exanthem in early pregnancy.  On examination, a grade 3 murmur is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's murmur?
questions.solution:
The image shows a bilateral cataract, which along with the antenatal history of viral exanthem is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

Frequency of heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
Beer's criteria is widely used for reducing the use of potentially inappropriate medications and polypharmacy in the geriatric population.

American Geriatric Society came up with Beer's criteria to review potentially inappropriate medications and avoid polypharmacy and deprescribe irrational medications due to the increased adverse effects of many drugs in the geriatric age group. This includes:

  • Explicit list of drugs that should be avoided in older adults
  • Drugs that should be avoided or be used at lower doses in patients with reduced kidney function
  • Specific drug-disease and drug-drug interactions that are known to be harmful in older adults

Long-acting benzodiazepines, proton pump inhibitors, antipsychotics, aspirin, dipyridamole, propoxyphene, and amitriptyline were among the most frequently prescribed inappropriate medications.

Medications like glimepiride, rivaroxaban, tramadol, and certain antipsychotic medications in patients with Parkinson's disease are recently added to the use-with-caution list.

Other options:

  • The Light's Criteria is used to differentiate between different causes of pleural effusions (transudative vs exudative).
  • The Jones Criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. 
  • The Duke's Criteria is used for the diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis (IE)

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush Scheme?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month). The diseases are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertusis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

 

 

 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It has been launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

In february 2020, the government launched Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI). The aim is to reach out to partially vaccinated and unvaccinated children with all the available vaccines under Universal Immunization Program (UIP) across 381 districts in 29 States/UTs.

questions.text: A patient is on magnesium sulfate therapy post-cesarean section for preeclampsia.  During her assessment after the 3rd maintenance dose, she has a respiratory rate of 8/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and a bilaterally absent knee reflex. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to manage this case?

choices.text: Stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate
Stop magnesium therapy and give oral calcium gluconate
Give half dose magnesium therapy and IV calcium gluconate
Skip the next maintenance dose and follow up

questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) toxicity is to stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. MgSO4 has to be administered up to 24 hrs after the last seizure (in postpartum seizure) or delivery, whichever is later.

Signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity include:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

It is treated by stopping magnesium therapy and giving slow IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) infusion. Fluid loading and forced diuresis are done and estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels. Before administering the maintenance dose of MgSO4, the above signs are checked. IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

 The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: Where is the pneumotaxic centre located?
questions.solution:
Pneumotaxic center is located in upper pons.

Neural regulation of respiration:

It involves set of neurons located in pons and medulla:

  • Pons:
    • Pneumotaxic centre

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events in Southern blotting?
A-  Transfer to a membrane, B- Hybridization with a labeled probe sequence, C- Separation of DNA fragments by electrophoresis
questions.solution:
• In Southern blotting DNA fragments are first separated by electrophoresis.
  • The DNA in the gel is then made single stranded by exposure to dilute alkali, and transferred by capillary action to the nylon membrane, which is laid over it.
  • The relative positions of the different DNA fragments are thus preserved on the membrane.
  • The membrane is then soaked in buffer containing the labelled probe, which base pairs with the DNA fragment of interest.
  • The position of that fragment is then determined by autoradiographic (exposure of the membrane to X-ray film), or fluorescent detection of the hybridized probe.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely related to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Most likely related to gastric volvulus is the Borchardt's triad.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.

The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include,

  • Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way
  • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
  • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2
  • Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
     

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A patient with a direct hernia is posted for Lichtenstein repair. Which of the following is used in the mesh?
questions.solution:
A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used.

Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is a propylene polymer. It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of a hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

Other options:

  • Polyglactin (Vicryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is commonly used in gut anastomoses, biliary anastomoses, and kidney and ureter surgeries.
  • Polyglycolic acid- Used for other absorbable sutures, in particular where slightly longer wound support is required.

questions.text: The Renal function is best assessed by:
questions.solution:
The Renal function is best assessed by Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine). It is eliminated through kidney as via both glomeruli filtration and tubular excretion.

  • Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.
  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. Also, it allows better assessment of differential renal function
  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence used for direct measurement of GFR.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever for 2 weeks and new-onset seizures. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) obtained on admission showed a 1.5 cm vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands as shown in the image below. What are these lesions called?
questions.solution:
The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes-are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual haemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's node. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

The image below depicts Roth's spots which are exudative lesions in the retina. This is an immunological phenomenon.

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male sustained head injury about 6 weeks back, following a road traffic accident. Now, he complains of increased frequency of micturition and passing large quantities of urine. He also complains of excessive thirst. Lesion involving which of the following nuclei of the hypothalamus is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
Lesion of the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus causes inhibition of the synthesis of vasopressin leading to diabetes insipidus.

The hypothalamus is a part of the diencephalon that lies below the thalamus. Anteriorly, the preoptic area is included in the hypothalamus. Posteriorly, it merges with the tegmentum of the midbrain. Laterally, it is bounded by the internal capsule.

Microscopically, the hypothalamus is divided into multiple nuclei.

Related Pearl: Functions of Main Hypothalamic Nuclei

 

Hypothalamic Nucleus Function
Supraoptic  Synthesizes vasopressin (ADH)
Paraventricular Synthesizes oxytocin
Preoptic & anterior Nuclei Control parasymphathetic system
Posterior & Lateral Control symphathetic system
Anterior Regulate temperature(response to heat)
Posterior Regulate temperature(response to cold)
Lateral

Initiate eating and increase food intake (Hunger center)
Increase water intake (Thirst center)
Medial

Inhibit eating and reduce food intake (satiety center)

Suprachiasmatic

 Controls circadian rhythm

questions.text: The cystographic appearance shown below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Christmas tree bladder or pine cone bladder is a cystogram appearance which usually seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.

  • A pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder is a cystogram appearance in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall.
  • It is typically seen in (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.
  • This finding is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It can also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a painless nodule on his left foot which ruptured to produce draining sinuses, with discharge of granules. What is this clinical condition likely to be?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with a typical case of mycetoma, mostly seen in tropical countries.
  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot

Chromoblastomycosis: Warty, cauliflower-like growth on the foot or lower leg.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in patients with Parkinson’s disease?
questions.solution:
Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are not a feature of Parkinson's disease. Cardinal motor features in PD include:

  • Resting tremors
  • Bradykinesia
  • Rigidity
  • Gait disturbance / postural instability

Mnemonic: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability

  • Other motor features include:
    • Micrographia
    • Masked facies (hypomimia)
    • Reduced eye blinking
    • Soft voice (hypophonia)
    • Dysphagia
  • Non-motor features are:
    • Anosmia
    • Sensory disturbance (pain)
    • Mood Disorders (depression)
    • Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder)
    • Autonomic:
      • GI disturbances
      • Genitourinary disturbances
      • Sexual dysfunction
      • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cognitive impairment

Parkinson’s disease(PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. UK Brain Bank criteria is used for the diagnosis of PD.

questions.text: The following instrument is:
questions.solution:
Ballenger swivel knife.

  • Used in removal of septal cartilage in SMR (Submucosal resection) operation.
  • The blade of the knife revolves automatically and changes direction when cutting the cartilage anteroposteriorly downwards and posteroanteriorly.

questions.text: A man is speaking about his mother's death and laughing. He is said to have:
questions.solution:
The man is speaking about his mother's death and is expected to be sad, but he is laughing. His laughter is not congruent with the content of his speech and thoughts. He has an incongruent affect. Congruency is described in relation to the thought content of the person.

Other options are:

  • Labile affect: excessive variations in emotion without any apparent reason. For example, a person starts laughing and then crying for no reason. Seen in mania.
  • Affective flattening/flat affect: severely restricted range of affect (absence of changes in emotion irrespective of the situation). Seen in schizophrenia.
  • Inappropriate affect: emotional responses that do not match with the social situation one is in. Appropriateness is described in relation to the social situation. For example, if a man is laughing at a funeral, he has an inappropriate affect.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. She also had frequent episodes of vomiting. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended post-evacuation for this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Administer anti-D if mother is Rh-ve
Allow pregnancy after 6 months of monitoring, if HCG titres are negative
Check hCG levels within 48 hours of evacuation
Can insert intrauterine devices for contraception

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance, post evacuation.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception-combination hormonal contraception, injectable depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, or progestin implant.
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation→ weekly until undetectable→ then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer. However, it is advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 year, preferably 2 years, as a fresh pregnancy will interfere with the hCG titres.

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: Laryngeal mask airway is relatively contraindicated in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is indicated in cases with difficult airway where endotracheal intubation is not possible or not available. It provides an alternate means of ventilating and oxygenating the patient. 

Relative Contraindications for the LMA:

  • Pharyngeal pathology – Abscess, tumor
  • Pharyngeal obstruction
  • Conditions with an increased risk of aspiration (eg: pregnancy, hiatal hernia, inadequate NPO) – LMA may protect the larynx from pharyngeal secretions but not from gastric secretions
  • Low pulmonary compliance (eg, restrictive airway disease)

The normal anatomic position of the LMA. The proximal portion of the LMA rests upon the epiglottis, whereas the distal end or, the tip extends into the pharynx at the upper end of the esophagus. The opening on the laryngeal mask overlies the laryngeal inlet.

questions.text: Which is the commonly noted vitamin deficiency In drought-affected areas?
questions.solution: The vitamin most commonly deficient in areas of famines and droughts is vitamin A; deficiency of this vitamin leads to xerophthalmia and blindness.

questions.text: The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is _________
questions.solution:
The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is anakinra.

It is a biological Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drug (DMARD) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and flaring of latent TB.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: What is the condition shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
The image shows Popeye sign and it is seen in rupture of proximal tendon of biceps.  Proximal tendon of biceps refers to both long head and short head of biceps.

Popeye sign: On flexing the elbow there is an extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly as its unrestrained fibers contract.

The proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function 

The 4 most common areas of tendon rupture include:

  • Quadriceps
  • Achilles
  • Rotator cuff (most commonly, the supraspinatus)
  • Biceps.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast.  The histopathological slide of the mass sample is given below. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates and pushing border.

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.
